awd_titl_txt: Hidden Costs of Decomposition: The Need for Fit between Technical and Organizational Architectures
awd_abstract_narration:
Engineered systems are becoming increasingly complex, and as a result, they are more difficult to design. Effective design requires quickly bringing diverse expertise to bear on each iteration of the design. These two goals -- faster design cycles and better cross-disciplinary integration -- are enabled by model-based concurrent design approaches. These approaches bring multiple experts together into a single room to create a design in a series of short design sessions, and they are widely used in certain fields, such as spacecraft design. These approaches have many proven advantages, but also potentially serious drawbacks due to the level of decomposition they impose on the design problem. For example, many assumptions are made in order to decompose the design tasks into modules for each team member, and these assumptions may not be valid for all design problems. This award supports fundamental research to generate knowledge about how the "fit" between the technical decomposition (the problem being solved) and the organizational decomposition (people and tasks) impacts the quality of the design process. The results will enable design organizations to make better informed choices about how to deploy concurrent design approaches, such as when these tools apply and when they do not, and how to use them well even when the technical and organizational decompositions are slightly mismatched. The resultant gains in design efficiency would have implications for many sectors of the economy that depend on engineering design and innovation. In addition, this research involves several disciplines including aerospace and systems engineering, organization design, and qualitative research methods; this approach will foster multi-disciplinary research and engineering education.

The objective of this research is to generate knowledge about how the lack of "fit" between a design organization's imposed decomposition and the problem's natural decomposition affect the speed and characteristics of the design process. The research will focus on understanding the nature of "fit," developing a framework for measuring it, identifying the types of problems that arise in the design process due to this lack of "fit," and explaining the mechanisms by which they arise. Current research in this area is limited by measurement challenges and limited empirical evidence. This research will address these limitations through an empirical study of the concurrent design team at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's Jet Propulsion Laboratory. The research will be conducted through an in-depth observational process study of multiple concurrent design sessions. The design process will be observed, its key characteristics measured, and the technical and organizational decompositions will be recorded, so that the impact of the decompositions' "fit" on the design process characteristics can be evaluated and its drivers explained.

por.por_cntn:
The development of new, complex engineered systems requires many engineers from many different disciplines to work together. One way to enable this is concurrent design, which brings together experts from multiple disciplines into a single room for focused design sessions -- which typically are fast and efficient. However, there are some potential hidden costs which may be incurred. Specifically, these fast and efficient design processes are enabled by dividing up, or decomposing, the design problem in a "standard" way, and following a "routine" process for when designers must coordinate to design their different parts of the spacecraft. When this standard structure and these routines are a good fit for the particular design problem, efficiency is improved. But when the design problem is novel in some way, such that the standard structure and routines are a poor fit, these efficiency shortcuts can cause designers to make poor choices and miss important trades.


It is therefore important to understand when and where such hidden costs might arise -- i.e., when we might expect a poor fit between the standard organizational structure/routines and the particular design problem at hand. This research project has explored this question through several related studies. We adapted existing frameworks for describing and comparing standard and "particular" structures, then computationally evaluated different ways to assess the degree of "fit" between them. We found that none of these existing measures were capable of capturing all the important "fit" problems that might arise. We also collected data by observing a series of NASA concurrent design studies, focusing on how much and when designers coordinated with one another and where there were successes or challenges in the design process. With these data, we identified the communication patterns of different types of designers. For example, we found a small number of integrators who are essential links across the different parts of the design throughout the entire design process, and many other designers with just a few strong links over limited time periods with other designers, shedding light on how design work is organized. In a related study, we also examined what influences the organization of the design process (such as technical and social factors) and its impact on performance. We also studied how different features of design problems could lead to problems with "fit" between the problem and the organizational structure/routine. We found that challenges confined to one designer's part of the problem create few challenges for "fit", but that design problems where challenges span multiple interconnected subsystems, and particularly those with unexpected interdependencies among designers who do not normally work together, can create large problems with "fit". These would likely lead to late discoveries of problems with the design -- as we saw in some of the observed NASA studies. 


In sum, then, we have motivated the study of "fit" between technical and organizational architectures as a potential cause of problems with the design process, and we have built measures and a framework for studying it. We have identified the types of novel design problems that are likely to create problems with fit, and thereby suggested guidelines for when "fit" problems may be anticipated and where organizational capacity must be adapted to accommodate them. Finally, we have explored communication patterns and their impact on design performance, to show what types of "fit" should be desirable -- in other words, how to plan organizational capacity for different technical architectures. These results can help design organizations to continue improving the speed and efficiency of their design processes while avoiding hidden costs resulting from poor fit between the organization and novel design problems. We continue to share our work and our findings with the NASA concurrent design facilities and with other researchers to support broad dissemination of this impact.
